title: Generation of human iPSC-derived neurofibromaspheres for in vitro and in vivo uses

Step-by-step method details
Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4] provides a schematic view of the major steps associated with this protocol.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2560-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Schematic representation of the major steps for the generation of neurofibromaspheres
d: days; NCSC: neural crest stem cells; SC: Schwann cells; ∗: change media.
Thawing and expansion of neural crest stem cells and neurofibroma-derived fibroblasts
Timing: 5–7 days
The purpose of this step is to expand previously prepared NCSC and Fb cultures in order to obtain enough cells to assemble neurofibromaspheres.
Thawing and expansion of NCSC.
Prepare a 15 mL conical centrifuge tube with 9 mL of DMEM:F12 (1:1).
Thaw 1 cryovial of NCSCs in a water bath at 37°C and transfer its content into the 15 mL conical centrifuge tube containing DMEM:F12 (1:1).
Centrifuge cells at 300 × g for 5 min at 22°C.
Discard supernatant.
Resuspend cells with 0.5 mL of NC media and transfer into 1 well of a 1:40 Matrigel-coated 6-well plate containing 1 mL NC media. Place the culture at 37°C with 5% CO2.
Replace medium every day, except weekends when you can add the double volume of the medium on Friday that will last until next Monday.
Expand NCSC as much as necessary (See “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]” steps 7d, e) to seed the cells at step 3.
Note: Calculate the number of 6-well plates containing NCSC to be prepared depending on the number of AggreWell microwells to be used. On average, 1 well of a 6-well plate contains around 2 × 106 NCSC.
Thawing and expansion of neurofibroma-derived Fbs.
Prepare a 15 mL conical centrifuge tube with 10 mL of complete DMEM.
Thaw 1 cryovial of Fbs in a water bath at 37°C and transfer its content into the 15 mL conical centrifuge tube containing complete DMEM.

Centrifuge cells at 300 × g for 5 min at 22°C.
Discard supernatant.
Resuspend cells with 10 mL of complete DMEM media and transfer into a 100 mm uncoated culture dish. Place the culture at 37°C with 5% CO2. Grow Fbs in 100 mm dishes until they reach 70%–80% confluency (See “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]” step 3).
Expand Fbs as necessary to generate neurofibromaspheres at step 4.
Note: Calculate the number of 100 mm dishes containing Fbs to be prepared depending on the number of AggreWell microwells to be used. On average, 1 dish of 100 mm contains around 1–2 × 106 Fbs.
Generation of neurofibromaspheres
Timing: 14 days
The purpose of this step is to generate neurofibromaspheres composed of NF1(−/−) iPSC-derived differentiating SCs mixed with neurofibroma-derived NF1 (+/-) Fbs in AggreWell 800 24-well plates. Each well of the 24-well plate contains 300 microcavities which allow the generation of 300 neurofibromaspheres.
We describe the procedure to prepare 1 well of an AggreWell 800 24-well plate. To prepare more wells, the number of NCSCs and Fbs plates to be prepared should be scaled, accordingly.
Differentiating NCSC towards SC in 2D for 5 days. Based on the protocol described by Ziegler et al.,10[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10] with modifications.
Preparing poly-L-Lysine and laminin-coated 6-well plates.
Coat 6-well plates with 1 mL/well of 0.1 mg/mL Poly-L-Lysine for 1 h at 22°C.
Aspirate Poly-L-Lysine and wash 2 times with PBS.
Add 1 mL of 4 μg/mL laminin/well for 1 h at 37°C or 16 h at 4°C.
Aspirate laminin and wash 2 times with PBS.
Plates are left in PBS until used.
Critical: Never let coated plates dry. If the incubation with laminin is at 4°C, plates must be sealed with plastic film to avoid evaporation.

Note: Plates can be stored at 4°C for several days. Poly-L-Lysine and laminin can be used for up to 2 weeks.
Plating NCSC in SC differentiation spheroid media in poly-L-Lysine and laminin-coated 6-well plates.
Wash NCSC with PBS.
Detach cells with 0.3 mL Accutase/well for 2–3 min at 37°C.
Collect cells gently with 2 mL/well DMEM:F12 (1:1) in a 15 mL conical centrifuge tube.
Centrifuge cells at 300 × g for 5 min at 22°C, remove supernatant and resuspend the cell pellet in 0.5 mL/well of SC Differentiation spheroid media.
Count cells.
Plate 4 × 105 NCSC/well onto 0.1 mg/mL poly-L-Lysine and 4 μg/mL laminin 6-well-coated plates in SC Differentiation spheroid media.
Replace media very gently on day 4 after seeding the cells.
On day five proceed to generate neurofibromaspheres (step 4).
Note: For NF1(+/+) NCSC, seed a complete 6-well plate to later prepare neurofibromaspheres in 1 well of a 24-well AggreWell plate. For NF1(−/−) NCSC, seed 3 wells of a 6-well plate to later prepare neurofibromaspheres in 1 well of a 24-well AggreWell plate.
Critical: Media replacement may detach differentiating cells. Be very gentle in changing the media. It is strongly recommended not to use a vacuum aspiration system in this step.
Assembling neurofibromaspheres in 3D at day 5 of SC differentiation.
Preparing spheroid plates (AggreWell 800 24-well plates) following the manufacturer’s instructions.
Open AggreWell 800 plates in a biosafety cabinet.
Pre-treat wells by adding 500 μL anti-adherence rinsing solution to each well to be used.
Prepare a centrifuge balance plate using a standard 24-well plate filled with 500 μL of water or PBS to match the weight and position of the AggreWell plate.
Centrifuge plate at 1,300 × g for 5 min in swinging bucket rotor fitted with plate holders using the balance plate.

Observe the plate under a microscope to ensure that bubbles have been removed from microwells. If bubbles remain trapped in any microwell, centrifuge at 1,300 × g for an additional 5 min.
Aspirate anti-adherence rinsing solution from the wells.
Rinse each well with 2 mL DMEM:F12 (3:1).
Aspirate medium from the well.
Add 0.5 mL/well warm SC Differentiation spheroid media to each well to be used.
Critical: Anti-adherence rinsing solution is required during plate preparation steps to ensure optimal performance. Anti-adherence rinsing solution prevents cell adhesion and promotes efficient spheroid formation.
Preparing NF1(−/−) 5-day-differentiating SCs (from step 3).
Wash 5-day differentiating SCs (step 3b) with 1 mL PBS.
Detach cells with 0.3 mL Accutase/well for 5 min at 37°C.
Collect cells gently with 2 mL/well DMEM:F12 (3:1) in a 15 mL conical centrifuge tube.
Centrifuge cells at 300 × g for 5 min at 22°C, remove supernatant and resuspend the cell pellet in 0.5 mL/well of SC Differentiation spheroid media.
Count cells.
Preparing neurofibroma-derived Fbs (from step 2).
Wash cells with 5 mL PBS.
Detach cells with 1 mL 0.25% Trypsin/dish for 5 min at 37°C.
Collect cells with 9 mL/dish complete DMEM media in a 15 mL conical centrifuge tube.
Centrifuge at 300 × g for 5 min, remove supernatant and resuspend in 1 mL/dish of SC Differentiation spheroid media.
Count cells.
Plating neurofibromaspheres in 24-well AggreWell plates (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2560-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Assembling neurofibromaspheres at day 5 of SC differentiation using AggreWell plates
(A) Tile scan of a single well of a 24-well plate showing the 300 neurofibromaspheres in the microcavities, 48 h after assembling.
(B) 9 microcavities with 9 neurofibromaespheres showing the assembling of them and evidencing the dislodge of one of them to another microcavity. See troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5].

(C) Neurofibromasphere 48 h (up) or 9 days (down) after assembling. Scale bar represents 75 μm.
Plate a total of 1.2 × 106 cells in each 24-well AggreWell plate by mixing 8.4 × 105 5-day differentiating SCs (70%) with 3.6 × 105 Fbs (30%) in 1.5 mL SC differentiation spheroid media for each well to be used.
Dispense the cell suspension into the AggreWell microwell containing 0.5 mL media.
Pipette cells up and down gently several times (using a P1000 pipette) to ensure an even distribution of cells throughout the well. Be careful not to introduce bubbles into the microwells.
Prepare a centrifuge balance plate using a standard 24-well plate filled with 2 mL of water or PBS to match the weight and position of the AggreWell plate.
Immediately after seeding the cells, centrifuge the AggreWell plate at 100 × g for 3 min to capture cells in the microwells using the balance plate.
Observe the plate under a microscope to verify that cells are evenly distributed in the microwells.
Incubate the plate at 37°C with 5% CO2.
Note: Prepare cell suspensions considering a final volume of 2 mL/well of a 24-well AggreWell plate.
Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5]: Neurofibromaspheres get attached to the bottom of the AggreWell microcavities.
Changing the medium of neurofibromaspheres.
Change spheroid media on days 8 and 12.
Warm SC Differentiation spheroid media at 22°C.
Perform a 50% medium change as follows:
Slowly remove 1 mL of medium from each well with a P1000 pipette.
Replace with 1 mL of fresh SC Differentiation spheroid media by slowly pipetting down the wall of the well.
Critical: Displacement of spheroids from microwells often occurs. Be careful when moving the plate and dispense and remove the medium very slowly.
Troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7]: Displacement of neurofibromaspheres in the AggreWell plates.

Harvesting neurofibromaspheres at day 14 of SC differentiation.
Cut the end of a P1000 pipette tip with sterile scissors and soak it in anti-adherence rinsing solution for 5 s.
Take 1 mL of the media from the AggreWell microwell and dispense it firmly back onto the surface of the plate to dislodge the spheroids from the microwells. Be gentle enough to avoid damaging the spheres.
Collect 1 mL media containing spheroids into a 15 mL conical centrifuge tube previously soaked in anti-adherence rinsing solution.
Clean the AggreWell microwell adding 4 mL SC Differentiation spheroid media and ensuring recollecting all the spheroids from each corner (1 mL per corner).
Centrifuge spheroids at 300 × g for 4 min at 22°C.
Aspirate the supernatant very gently using a 5 mL pipette first and a 200 μL pipette tip, leaving around 40 μL of media containing the spheroids.
At this point, you can use spheroids for different applications (see below).
Critical: Spheroids are very sticky. Always use anti-adherence rinsing solution to treat all tips and tubes to be used with spheroids.
Troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9]: Neurofibromaspheres sticking into plastic tips, and plastic centrifuge tubes while manipulating them.
Validation and quality check of neurofibromasperes
The purpose of these steps is to validate the correct formation of neurofibromaspheres by analysis of lineage marker expression. We propose two different ways of validation. One is straightforward and relies on the detection of SC marker expression by immunofluorescence (Validation 1). The second is optional and relies on the transcriptome analysis of neurofibromasheres to get a better sense of cellular heterogeneity within neurofibromaspheres (Validation 2).
Validation 1: Detection of SC lineage markers by immunofluorescence of neurofibromaspheres
Timing: 2 days
The purpose of this step is to confirm the expression of p75 and S100B, two SC markers, in neurofibromaspheres.

Note: Immunostaining will be performed in suspension.
Immunofluorescence of neurofibromaspheres (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2560-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. Immunofluorescence analysis of p75 (green) and S100B (red)
DAPI was used to stain nuclei. Scale bar represents 100 μm.
Cut the end of a P1000 pipette tip with sterile scissors and soak it in anti-adherence rinsing solution.
Using the cut soaked tip take neurofibromaspheres from step 5g, and transfer them into a 1.5 mL low-binding tube previously soaked in anti-adherence rinsing solution.
Let neurofibromaspheres precipitate at the bottom of the tube by gravity and slowly remove as much supernatant as possible with a pipette tip.
Note: Repeat this procedure to remove solutions in the following steps.
Fixation: add 200 μL 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) and fix spheres for 30 min at 22°C.
Let neurofibromaspheres precipitate at the bottom of the tube by gravity and remove PFA.
Wash 1 time with 200 μL PBS for 10 min. Remove PBS
Permeabilization: add 200 μL of 0.1%Triton-X 100 in PBS for 10 min at 22°C. Remove permeabilization solution.
Blocking: add 200 μL 10% FBS in PBS for 15 min at 22°C. Remove the blocking solution.
Incubation with primary antibodies: add 100 μL of primary antibodies (1:100 p75 and 1:1000 S100B) diluted in 1% FBS in PBS. Incubate for 16 h at 4°C. Remove the primary antibody solution.
Wash 3 times with 200 μL 1% FBS in PBS for 10 min each.
Incubation with secondary antibodies: add 100 μL of secondary antibody mix (1:1000 AF 488 goat anti-mouse IgG and 1:1000 AF 568 goat anti-rabbit IgG) diluted in 10% FBS in PBS for 1 h at 22°C protected from light. Remove the secondary antibody solution.
Wash 3 times with 200 μL 1% FBS in PBS for 10 min each.

Counterstaining: add 100 μL of DAPI diluted in PBS (1:1000). Incubate for 10 min at 22°C protected from light. Remove DAPI solution.
Wash 1 time with 100 μL PBS. Remove the PBS wash and let a small residual volume (approx. 40 μL).
Cut the end of a P1000 pipette tip with sterile scissors and soak it in an anti-adherence rinsing solution.
Using the cut-soaked tip and the residual PBS, transfer the neurofibromaspheres into a slide and spread them carefully. At this point, neurofibromaspheres can be seen as tiny mounds that modify the flat surface of the liquid. Using a swap, remove the remaining liquid without touching neurofibromaspheres.
Once the maximum possible liquid has been removed, add 40–50 μL of Vectashield mounting medium on top and place a coverslip. Secure it with nail polish.
Analyze immunofluorescence using fluorescence or a confocal microscope.
Critical: Spheroids are very sticky. Always use an anti-adherence rinsing solution to treat all tips and tubes to be used while manipulating spheroids.
Critical: Step 6p requires patience, good eyesight, and a source of light.
Validation 2: Transcriptome analysis of neurofibromaspheres
Timing: 2 h for RNA extraction; RNAseq; 1 week for bioinformatic analysis
The purpose of this step is to validate the correct generation of neurofibromaspheres by transcriptome analysis.
Transcriptional quality control for neurofibromaspheres.
Extract total RNA from neurofibromaspheres from step 5g using the 16 LEV simplyRNA purification Kit following the manufacturer’s instructions in The Maxwell 16 Instrument or any other RNA extraction methodology.
Quantify total RNA using a Nanodrop spectrophotometer.
Prepare RNA-seq libraries using the TruSeq Stranded Total RNA Library Prep Gold.
Quantify using the KAPA library quantitation kit.
Prepare your RNA-seq data and perform quality check (QC) analysis of your neurofibromaspheres following the steps described at: https://github.com/TranslationalBioinformaticsIGTP/STARProtocols_Mazuelas_2022[href=https://github.com/TranslationalBioinformaticsIGTP/STARProtocols_Mazuelas_2022] (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.7118682).

Critical: Read carefully the “Readme” file steps to perform the QC.
Troubleshooting 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.11]: Incorrect neurofibromasphere differentiation into SC lineage.
Engrafting neurofibromaspheres into nude mice
Timing: 1 h for preparing the cells and 15 min for surgery procedures per mouse
This procedure consists in injecting neurofibromaspheres orthotopically into the sciatic nerve of nude mice to generate human neurofibroma-like tumors. The procedure is based on the protocol described by Chen et al.11[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11] with modifications.
Preparing neurofibromaspheres for injection (starting from step 5g).
Prepare 1 sterile low-binding 1.5 mL tube per injection to be made and soak it in anti-adherence rinsing solution.
Place tubes on ice and when they get cold add 40 μL of non-diluted Matrigel to each tube. Keep them on ice all time.
Add 40 μL of media containing the neurofibromaspheres from step 5g to the tubes containing Matrigel and mix gently. Keep them on ice until the injection.
Injecting neurofibromaspheres into the sciatic nerve of nude mice (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2560-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. Injecting neurofibromaspheres into the sciatic nerve of nude mice
(A) Picture showing the sciatic nerve (arrow) of an anesthetized mouse just before the injection of neurofibromaspheres.
(B) Picture showing a sutured mouse just after the injection of neurofibromaspheres and before closing the skin with surgical staples.
Place 25G syringes to be used for injection on dry ice to maintain them very cold.
Set up the surgical table with all the surgical instruments.
30 min before the surgery, inject Buprenorphine (0.1 mg/kg) subcutaneously into 6-week-old athymic nude mice (housed in a sterile environment, in cages with autoclaved bedding, food, and water. Mice are maintained on a daily 12 h light, 12 h dark cycle).
Anesthetize mice using 4% isoflurane, and maintain them in 2% during surgery.

Disinfect the skin over the biceps femoris muscle from one of the rear limbs with povidone-iodine.
Cut the skin with scissors.
Make a small incision using a scissor in the biceps femoris muscle to display the sciatic nerve (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]A).
Soak the cold syringe with cold anti-adherence rinsing solution.
Take the mixture of neurofibromaspheres and Matrigel into the cold syringe and inject them in close contact with the sciatic nerve.
Close the muscle with a polypropylene suture 7/0 (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]B).
Close the skin using surgical staples.
Administer meloxicam subcutaneously once a day for two days (2 mg/kg).
Remove staples after 10 days.
Follow tumor growth weekly by palpation.
After 4 months animals are sacrificed by cervical dislocation and the rear limbs are removed for dissection.
Critical: Load the syringe with the mix cells and Matrigel just after visualization of the sciatic nerve to avoid solidification of Matrigel in the Syringe.
Troubleshooting 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.13]: Matrigel solidification in the syringe containing neurofibromaspheres.
Dissecting gastrocnemius muscle to collect humanized neurofibromas in mice
Timing: 30 min to dissect 1 limb
In our hands, iPSC-derived tumors grow attached to the gastrocnemius (GC) muscle or inside it. The purpose of this step is to provide a detailed description of how to dissect the mouse limb, and the GC muscle to collect the tumors.
Dissection of the gastrocnemius muscle.
Pin the mouse limb in a prone position using 4 needles. Peel off the skin to expose the lower leg muscles.
Remove the fascia around GC muscle using micro scissors. Avoid pinching and cutting the muscle.
Pinch the Achilles tendon of the GC and soleus muscle with Jeweler’s forceps, and cut the Achilles tendon while holding it with scissors.

With the Achilles tendon subjected to one pair of forceps, place another pair of Jeweler’s forceps between the bone and the GC and slide it along the bone toward the posterior part of the knee joint to detach the GC muscle from the bone.
While subjecting the Achilles tendon, cut the ligaments close to the posterior part of the knee joint using micro scissors to isolate GC muscle.
Tumors should be located attached to the GC muscle (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]Ai) or inside it (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]Aii).

Figure 8. Dissection of the gastrocnemius (GC) muscle to collect neurofibroma-like tumors
(A) Representative images showing neurofibroma-like tumors that grew attached to the GC muscle (i) or inside it (ii).
(B) H&E stained neurofibroma-like tumors grown attached to the GC muscle (i) or as independent tumor masses (ii). Scale bar represents 1 cm.
Note: At this point, tumors are either OCT-embedded or fixed and paraffin-embedded for subsequent H&E morphological characterization (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]B) and SC lineage marker staining (SOX10, S100B). To validate the human origin of tumor cells, the human antigen markers hNu (OCT) or Ku80 (paraffin) can be used.
